Situation1: They notice their parents appear more stressed and tired than usual.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I noticed lately that my parents have been quieter, their faces drawn with worry and fatigue. At dinner, my mom barely touched her food, and my dad kept sighing, lost in thought. I know they need me—to sit with them, to listen, to offer comfort. As their son, I feel responsible for being present, especially now when they seem so fragile. But this week, like every week, my church expects me to be there for Sunday service and the youth group meeting afterward. I’m supposed to help set up, greet newcomers, and join the prayer circle. My pastor always says our commitment to the church community is a reflection of our faith. I feel torn. If I stay home, I worry I’ll let down my church family and maybe even my faith. If I go, I’ll leave my parents alone when they need me most. The weight of both expectations presses on me, and I can’t shake the feeling that, no matter what I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
